children.name: complain
children.definition: to say that you are annoyed, not satisfied, or unhappy about something or someone: phàn nàn
examples: Residents are complaining because traffic in the area has increased.
‘You never ask my opinion about anything,’ Rod complained.

children.name: complain bitterly
children.definition: in a very angry way
examples: My grandfather’s always complaining bitterly about how expensive things are.

children.name: complain loudly
examples: The kids were complaining loudly about the heat.

children.name: constantly complain
examples: She was constantly complaining about her job.

children.name: have the right to complain
examples: You have the right to complain if you’re not satisfied with the service you’re getting.

children.name: have
children.definition: good
examples: reason to complainWe felt we had good reason to complain about the food at the hotel.

children.name: have little/no reason to complain
examples: The school is good and parents have little reason to complain.

children.name: have cause to complain
examples: Patients sometimes have cause to complain about the hospital treatment they receive.

children.name: be in a position to complain
children.definition: have a good reason to complain
examples: If you feel you are bullied at work, you are certainly in a position to complain.

children.name: be the first to complain
children.definition: be quick to complain
examples: He’s the first to complain if he thinks something is unfair.

children.name: complain (that)
examples: She complained that no one had been at the airport to meet her.

children.name: complain about
examples: She often complains about not feeling appreciated at work.

children.name: complain of
examples: Several women have complained of sexual harassment.

children.name: complain to
examples: Neighbours complained to the police about the dogs barking.

children.name: make a complaint
children.definition: toformallycomplain about sth to sb in authority: khiếu lại
examples: Write to this address if you wish to make a complaint.

children.name: make a complaint to
examples: Parents made a complaint to the principal about bullying in the school.
His parents made a complaint to the head teacher.

children.name: lodge a complaint
children.definition: UK /file a complaintUS  to make anofficialcomplaint, usually inwriting, to sb in authority: đệ đơn khiếu lại
examples: She went to the city council and lodged a complaint.

children.name: lodge a complaint with
examples: The company said it plans to file a complaint with the International Trade Commission.

children.name: lodge a complaint against
examples: Conyers said she had been blocked from promotion after filing a complaint against a male co-worker.

children.name: protest
children.definition: to complain about sth, especiallypubliclyorofficially, because you areannoyedor think it isunfair: phản kháng kháng nghị
examples: He was carried away in a police van, protesting loudly.

children.name: protest about
examples: Passengers protested angrily about increased rail fares.

children.name: protest to
examples: The journalists have protested to government officials about the way they were treated.

children.name: protest (that)
examples: Dan protested it wasn’t him who had caused the problems.

children.name: protest your innocencesay that you are innocent
examples: Mills, who has been in prison since 1987, has always protested his innocence.

children.name: take it up with U
children.definition: take it up with/ take the matter up with to speak or write to sb in authority complaining about sth: phàn nàn
examples: I told her she should take it up with her local council.
Alton said he was prepared to take the matter up with the Ministry of Health if necessary.

children.name: air your grievances
children.definition: to talk about the things you are unhappy or annoyed about, especially in public to people in authority so that they can do sth about them: thổ lộ sự bất bình, than phiền
examples: The meeting gave employees an opportunity to air their grievances.
The uprising at Southport prison ended after inmates were allowed to air their grievances to the media.

children.name: complaint
children.definition: 1 a statement in which someone complains about something :
examples: If you wish to make a complaint, you should see the manager.
The sales assistants are trained to deal with customer complaints in a friendly manner.
complaint about
Keating was dismissed after complaints about the quality of his work.
complaint of
complaints of police brutality
complaint from/to
complaints from local residents
a complaint to the Advertising Standards Authority
complaint against
All complaints against police officers are carefully investigated.
complaint that
We are concerned by complaints that children are being bullied.
2[C] something that you complain about :
Our main complaint was the poor standard of service.
My only complaint is that the price is rather high.

children.name: make a complaint
children.definition: complain formally to someone
examples: The manager of the team decided to make a complaint about the referee.

children.name: file/lodge a complaintformal
children.definition: make a complaint
examples: She filed a complaint against several of her colleagues.

children.name: have a complaint
children.definition: want to complain about something
examples: Please let us know if you have any complaints about our service.

children.name: bring a complaint against somebodyformal
children.definition: complain in a formal, legal way
examples: Higgins brought a complaint against his former manager.

children.name: receive a complaint
children.definition: alsohave a complaint
examples: Our department has received a number of complaints from the public.

children.name: deal with/handle a complaint
examples: Police officers came to the house to deal with a complaint about noise.

children.name: investigate a complaint
examples: The dog was rescued after officials investigated a complaint of neglect.

children.name: uphold a complaint
children.definition: say it is reasonable
examples: The complaint was upheld and the advertisement was withdrawn.

children.name: a complaint concerns something/relates to something
examples: We have received a number of complaints concerning faulty goods.

children.name: a formal/official complaint
examples: The man has lodged a formal complaint against the police.

children.name: a common/widespread/frequent complaint
examples: A common complaint of children is that parents do not listen to them.

children.name: a serious complaint
examples: Serious complaints of negligence have been made.

children.name: a customer/consumer complaint
examples: As a result of the improvements, customer complaints went down by 70%.

children.name: a bitter complaint
children.definition: a very angry one
examples: The people are full of bitter complaints about their government.

children.name: a familiar complaint
children.definition: one that you have heard many times
examples: A lack of good public transport is a familiar complaint.

children.name: cause/grounds for complaint
children.definition: a good reason to complain
examples: I do not think that he has any cause for complaint.

children.name: a letter of complaint
examples: I wrote a letter of complaint to the hospital manager.

children.name: a complaints procedure
children.definition: a system for dealing with complaints
examples: There is a very straightforward complaints procedure you must follow.

children.name: protest
children.definition: when sb complains publicly about sth that they think is wrong or unfair and should not be allowed to happen: lời phản đối, kháng nghị
examples: Despite their protests, the students’ fees were increased.

children.name: without protest
examples: He accepted his punishment without protest.

children.name: protest from
examples: I turned off the TV, despiteloud protestsfrom the kids.

children.name: in protestas a way of making a protest trong kháng nghị
examples: When two members of the team were dismissed, the rest of them walked out in protest.

children.name: protest against
examples: The ambassador lodged a formal protest against the proposals.

children.name: ignore sb’s protests
examples: Ignoring my protests, he took off his jacket and wrapped it around my shoulders.

children.name: outcry
children.definition: /ˈaʊtkraɪ/  an angry protest by a lot of people about something that they think is very wrong or unfair: la ó, la thét
examples: ▪ Despite an outcry, the university refused to change its admission policies.

children.name: public outcry
examples: ▪ The shooting of an unarmed teenager by police caused a public outcry.

children.name: outcry about/over
examples: ▪ There was a widespread outcry over the increase in fuel tax.

children.name: outcry against
examples: ▪ The public outcry against the executions made little difference.

children.name: grievance
children.definition: sth that you feel unhappy about because you think that you have been treated unfairly - use this especially about an official complaint you make about the place where you work: lời phàn nàn, lời than phiền
examples: She filed a grievance last year after her supervisor refused to promote her.

children.name: a genuine grievance
children.definition: one that is definitely true
examples: He felt that he had a genuine grievance and was prepared to take the company to court over the matter.

children.name: a legitimate grievance
children.definition: one that is reasonable
examples: Many people feel that the rebels have a legitimate grievance.

children.name: an old grievance
children.definition: one that you have felt unhappy about for a long time
examples: Years later, we became friends again and sorted out our old grievances.

children.name: a personal grievance
examples: He has no personal grievance against Frank.

children.name: have a grievance
children.definition: against somebody
examples: I had no grievance against him.

children.name: air your grievances
children.definition: tell people you think you have been treated unfairly
examples: These committees act as a forum for various groups to air their grievances.

children.name: nurse a grievance
children.definition: think a lot or for a long time about the fact you have been treated unfairly
examples: He was nursing a grievance about not being picked for the team.

children.name: file a grievanceAmerican English
children.definition: officially complain
examples: She filed a grievance after failing to get a promotion.

children.name: settle a grievance
children.definition: solve one
examples: The union decided to settle its grievance in the law courts.

children.name: redress/remedy a grievanceformal
children.definition: do something to make a problem better
examples: Governments which have not redressed genuine grievances often pay a heavy price later on.

children.name: a grievance procedure
children.definition: a system for dealing with employees' grievances
examples: You should pursue your complaint through the company's grievance procedure.

children.name: a sense of grievance
children.definition: when you feel that you have been treated unfairly
examples: Anti-Americanism in these countries comes from a deep sense of grievance against the United States.

children.name: a source of grievance
children.definition: something that causes grievance
examples: Salaries are a traditional source of grievance in industry.

children.name: grievance against
examples: Anyone who has a legitimate grievance against the company can take it to the arbitration committee.

children.name: gripe
children.definition: /graɪp/  informal something unimportant that you keep complaining about or feel unhappy about: kêu ca, phàn nàn
examples: ▪ Students’ main gripe is the poor quality of the dorm food.
▪ I left the house because I wasn’t in the mood to listen to Maude’s gripes.

children.name: to complain a lot in an annoying way
moan
children.definition: /məʊn/  especially British,informalto keep complaining in an annoying way- use this about someone who complains all the time, even about things that are not important: than van , rền rĩ
examples: I’m fed up with hearing you moaning the whole time!
‘I feel seasick already,’ she moaned.

children.name: moan about
examples: A lot of people moaned about the parking problems.
moan atBritish English:
My mum never stops moaning at me.

children.name: moan that
examples: He’s always moaning that we use too much electricity.
Hemoaned and groanedall the way there.

children.name: grumble
children.definition: to keep complaining in abad-temperedway, especially when you think you have been treatedunfairly: lầm bầm
examples: The old man turned away, grumbling as he went.

children.name: grumble that
examples: A few passengers grumbled that their cabins were too small.
‘This is boring,’ Kathleen grumbled.

children.name: grumble about/at
examples: Farmers are always grumbling about the weather.
She was grumbling about having to work so late.
The people standing beside me were grumbling about not being able to find a place to park.

children.name: make a fuss
children.definition: especially British/kick up a fussBritish  to complainangrilyandnoisilyabout sth, so thateveryonehearsyou or notices you: làm ầm lên
examples: I don’t understand why you’re making such a fuss. It’s not that important.

children.name: make a fuss about
examples: The couple sitting next to us made a big fuss about their bill.

children.name: go on about
children.definition: UK informal to keep complaining about something or someone’s behaviour in an annoying way: lải nhải
examples: Our neighbours are always going on about the noise we make.

children.name: go on and on aboutfor a long time lải nha lải nhải
examples: Look, I’m sorry I kept you waiting, but there’s no need to go on and on about it.

children.name: nag
children.definition: to keep complaining to sb, especially in order to make them do sth that they do not want to do: đay nghiến, trì triết, cằn nhằn
examples: ▪ I wish you’d stop nagging me.nag about
▪ My mom’s always nagging me about my room.nag at
▪ Jane’s boss nags at her all the time.
nagging[U]
constant/incessant etc nagging
I don’t know how you put up with Claire’s constant nagging.

children.name: whinge
children.definition: Britishinformalto keep complaining in an annoying way - use this when sb is complaining about sth that is not important or is sth they could change if they really wanted to: mè nheo

children.name: whinge about
examples: He’s always whinging about being underpaid.
Nick was a pain in the neck. He did nothing but whinge the whole trip.

children.name: whine
children.definition: /waɪn/  to keep complaining about something unimportant, especially in a sad, annoying voice: than vãi, rên rỉ
examples: ▪ ‘What did you do that for?’ he whined.
▪ For heaven’s sake stop whining. Nobody has touched your precious records.

children.name: whine about
examples: ▪ He’s always whining about how much everything costs.

children.name: grouch
children.definition: /graʊtʃ/  sb who is always complaining: tính hay than phiền , hay hờn dỗi
examples: ▪ Her dad’s a terrible grouch.
▪ You’re such a grouch in the morning.

children.name: whinger
children.definition: British informal sb who keeps complaining in an annoying way - use this when someone is complaining about something that is not important or is something they could change if they wanted to: người hay cằn nhằn, càu nhàu
examples: This place is full of whingers. It’s just pathetic.

children.name: misery
children.definition: /misery guts/ˈmɪzəri, ˈmɪzəri ˌgʌts/  British informal sb who is always complaining, is never happy, and does not like other people to enjoy themselves: than vãn, "bất hạnh"
examples: ▪ Emma is a real misery guts.
▪ Stop being such a misery. It’s not the end of the world.

children.name: represent
children.definition: formal to express or complain about sth, to a person in authority : đệ trình
examples: We represented our grievances/demandstothe boss.
